title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It establishes the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising purposes, limited to 10% of the transferred amounts, not exceeding $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for advertising expenses under section 314 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. The Administrator can use up to $200,000 annually for administering prize competitions, and any remaining funds can be used for prizes. The Fund can be invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments in the NASA Innovation Fund can only be made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. These obligations can be acquired on original issue at the issue price or by purchasing outstanding obligations at the market price. Any obligation held in the Fund can be sold at market price, with the interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption being credited to the Fund. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. The members come from academia, nonprofit, and private sectors, with a Chair and Vice Chair appointed by the Administrator. The Advisory Committee for the NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. Members serve three-year terms with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. The Advisory Committee members serve three-year terms with a limit of 6 years. They are not compensated but reimbursed for expenses. Meetings must occur at least 4 times a year, with the option for additional meetings. The Administrator and NASA officers must be present at meetings. The Advisory Committee meets at least 4 times a year, with the option for additional meetings. The Administrator and NASA officers must attend to provide guidance. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A person approved for the program is known as a "sponsor". The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner". The Advisory Committee will recommend the design of the Partnership Logo for the NASA Innovation Fund Partner. To apply as a sponsor, a person must submit an application with the amount to be contributed and a description of their promotional program using the logo. The Partnership Logo is used by individuals planning to develop educational programs in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. This includes presenting educational information, promoting programs in STEM fields, and encouraging study and employment opportunities. Approved applicants must enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator. Approved applicants under subsection (c) must enter a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator. The agreement requires providing a specified amount and allows the use of the Partnership Logo in promotional programs. Restrictions include no logos on spacecraft and no astronaut endorsements in advertisements. The Administrator establishes restrictions on endorsements, contributions, and proprietary information protection for approved sponsorship agreements. The Administrator establishes procedures to protect proprietary information and encourages NASA to participate in promotional programs. Unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo is enforced by the Administrator. The Administrator can take legal action against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo, including seeking injunctions and imposing civil penalties of $100,000 per violation. Any penalties collected will be transferred to the Fund. The Administrator has the authority to take legal action for preventive relief, such as injunctions, against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo. A report must be submitted to Congress annually detailing actions taken by NASA, including financial statements and an evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee is required to consult yearly. The Advisory Committee consults annually with NASA Centers to improve the program authorized under this section and section 4. SEC. 5 amends section 314(i) of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. SEC. 6 defines key terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
